official-title.#text:
To provide for the establishment of a Commission to
		  Accelerate the End of Breast Cancer.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Accelerating the End of Breast Cancer
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The table of contents
			 of this Act is as follows:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The

In the United
			 States, the chance of a woman developing breast cancer during her lifetime has
			 increased from 1 in 11 in 1975 to 1 in 8 today.

Worldwide, breast
			 cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer in women with 1.3 million cases
			 each year and the leading cause of cancer death with more than 500,000 women
			 dying from the disease in 2010.

More than 90
			 percent of deaths from breast cancer are caused by metastasis, when breast
			 cancer has spread to other organs or bone.

The National
			 Cancer Institute estimated that breast cancer care in the United States cost
			 $16.5 billion in 2009 and cost the Nation $12.1 billion in lost
			 productivity.

Very little has improved in terms of breast
			 cancer incidence, morbidity, and mortality rates over the past 40 years.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall establish a commission

(in this

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Commission to Accelerate the End of Breast Cancer

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall be to
			 help end breast cancer by January 1, 2020.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Commission to Accelerate the End of Breast Cancer

text.#text: The mission of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Commission to Accelerate the End of Breast Cancer

text.#text: The

identify
			 opportunities and ideas within government and the private sector that are key
			 components in achieving the end of breast cancer and which have been
			 overlooked, yet are ripe for collaboration and investment, and

recommend projects
			 to leverage such opportunities and ideas in the areas of—

the primary
			 prevention of breast cancer; and

the causes and
			 prevention of breast cancer metastasis.

			 ending breast cancer by January 1, 2020.
